newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore lowers petrol prices after two years.
newsitem.headline: Singapore lowers petrol prices after two years.

text.p: Singapore petrol retailers are reducing their pump prices for the first time in around two years amid soft international prices since early June, industry sources said on Tuesday.
Mobil Oil Singapore, the first to reduce prices on July 1, dropped prices as a result of a "downward trend in wholesale prices", the company spokeswoman said.
An abundance of supplies have depressed international spot prices for diesel and petrol (gasoline).
In mid-June, diesel prices fell to their lowest since November 1995 while gasoline fell to a 10-month low.
The three grades of petrol sold in the city state were being reduced by one Singapore cent per litre and diesel by two cents.
The latest price move will lower prices to Singapore $1.216 ($0.85) per litre for the unleaded 98-octane grade, S$1.15 for unleaded 92-octane and S$1.337 for premium leaded and S$0.551 for diesel.
But Singapore pump prices are still one of the highest in Asia.
"The market is softening but in Singapore, we also have to take into consideration property prices and the rising costs of the station sites," a source said.
"It has been quite some time since prices fell, but whenever we can afford it, we will pass savings on to the consumer," he said.
Shell, British Petroleum and Singapore Petroleum Co told Reuters they were planning to lower prices later on Tuesday or on Wednesday.
The remaining two of the six retailers, Exxon Corp and Caltex, a Chevron Corp and Texaco Inc joint venture, were unavailable for comment but sources expected them to follow suit.
"Everybody will fall into position in a matter of three days," a source said. "In such a small market you can't hold on too long or you will lose sales and credibility."
Sources estimated annual petrol retail sales were around 5.3 million barrels and diesel sales around 2.3 million barrels.
